subject: Re: [junit] Future of testing tools
msgSnippet: Or do it in reverse. Declare private methods on the Class, and have the builder create the ClassHelper. ...
messageBody:
Or do it in reverse.

Declare private methods on the Class, and have the
builder create the ClassHelper.


--- Ole Ersoy <ole_ersoy@...> wrote:

> One way to have your cake and eat it too would
> be to use the Class + ClassHelper structure/pattern
> to do the initial coding and testing.
>
> Then a builder creates a parallel project merging
> the
> Class with the ClassHelper, privatizing the
> ClassHelper's methods in the process.
>
> Cheers,
> - Ole
>
>
>
>
> --- Michael Feathers <mfeathers@...>
> wrote:
>
> > David Saff wrote:
> >
> > >On 2/14/07, Michael Feathers
> > <mfeathers@...> wrote:
> > >
> > >
> > >>In general, I think it would be great to see
> > environments which give us
> > >>much more information about our programs.
> Another
> > example.. a while ago
> > >>I was talking to Ivan Moore (of Jester fame) and
> > he was saying that he
> > >>had an idea for a tool that would go through
> your
> > Java code and
> > >>'privitize' it; that is, make all methods
> private
> > that could be
> > >>private. In the spirit of the thing he was
> > thinking of calling it
> > >>Thatcher :-) We were talking about it with a
> few
> > other people who, like
> > >>me, are very annoyed by the fact that private
> gets
> > in the way when its
> > >>in someone else's mangled code and you don't
> have
> > the opportunity to
> > >>peel it off, and we thought, well, wouldn't it
> be
> > nice if your
> > >>environment just told you which methods weren't
> > used elsewhere in the
> > >>system? Sort of, "this one could be private if
> > you wanted it to be."
> > >>
> > >>
> > >
> > >Michael,
> > >
> > >Very interesting. Are you suggesting this tool
> > would allow you to
> > >make more things private, or allow you to leave
> > fewer things private,
> > >while still having the documentary benefit from
> the
> > IDE of an "only
> > >used locally" marker?
> > >
> > >
> > You could use it either way and as long as a
> > language has private,
> > people would probably move to one or the other
> > style.
> >
> > I think that the core issue behind all of this is
> > what we choose to
> > think of as the program. For languages like Java
> > which are file-based,
> > that have representation outside the IDE, I
> suppose
> > there will always be
> > people who want to see those semantics in the
> > source. The thing that is
> > interesting to consider, though, is that if our
> IDEs
> > can infer this
> > information, is there much merit in the idea of
> > having the programmer
> > specify it? Could it be enough to say, well, you
> > can access whatever
> > you want, but the uses will be immediately
> apparent
> > when people look at
> > the code.
> >
> > Typing 'private' is a like a little ritual. You
> are
> > documenting a
> > decision. But, if you have control over the code,
> > you can "untype" it
> > whenever you want to. This is pretty much the
> same
> > as having the IDE
> > infer it for you. The only way that private has
> > teeth is when you don't
> > have control over the code that uses it. And, as
> a
> > guy who runs into
> > testing dilemmas all the time, I have to say that
> > those teeth feel very
> > sharp.
> >
> > One way out of this might be to let IDEs manage
> > private the way that
> > Eclipse manages imports. I haven't thought that
> > through yet.. might be
> > neat though.
> >
> > Michael Feathers
